content: Collection consists of interviews with nisei and sansei talking about the japanese american community in alameda, california . Project partners include the internet archive (archive.org), the alameda library, the buddhist temple of alameda . The goal of the project is to reach and educate the world wide general public .

This collection consists of interviews conducted during the "then they came for me: incarceration of japanese americans during wwii and the demise of civil liberties" The majority of these interviews focus on both pre-war life, wartime incarceration, and postwar resettlement to chicago and the midwest .

Collection contains correspondence, photographs, articles, chronologies, rosters, books, booklets, programs, reunion yearbook, and album . depicts americans of japanese ancestry’s military service, mainly anti-tank company, 100th infantry battalion, 442nd regimental combat team, and military intelligence service .

Collection documents the administrative duties of willard schmidt, the chief of internal security for the war relocation authority and the tule lake incarceration/segregation camp . In 1943, the camp was turned into a segregation center to house "disloyal" japanese americans relocated from other camps based on loyalty questionnaire .

The photo album is a collection of tule lake incarceration camp photos . The album highlights toshio oku (1925-2010), the son of naojiro oku and misao oku . The photos include photos of a fire, group photo of the electrical department, inside the print shop of the newell star .

Collection contains mainly correspondence between emiko and usami terada, incarcerees in the rohwer incarceration camp, mcgehee arkansas, and the thomas family in lawndale, california . Also included are photographs taken in the camp and fliers published during wartime .

The okine collection was collected by seiichi and tomeyo okine who were issei flower growers in whittier, california . It includes correspondence, photographs, financial documents, and a photo album . The collection includes a family photo album compiled by dorothy ai aoki, a nisei daughter to the okines .

Interview of edwin (ed) sasaki, a professor of the psychology department, conducted by the public history institute at california state university, bakersfield . Professor sasaki recollects his family’s experiences during the world war ii, being arrested as a suspect and incarcerated in tule lake after the attack on pearl harbor .

The crystal city peruvian letters collection contains three letters written by kiyoko and yoshihiko matsuura, japanese peruvians interned at the crystal city internment, texas, to their mother/grandmother . Collection of mostly photographs compiled by tazuko "tazu" kawamoto that document various people, events, and activities throughout 1939-1943 . Collection also has photographs most likely taken inside the gila river incarceration camp in arizona, including a photograph of dentists at the community hospital .

This collection contains one box of documents belonging to tsugitada kanamori . materials in this collection mostly pertain to his efforts regarding canceling his renunciation and reinstating his american citizenship . This collection is courtesy of the department of archives and special collections. california state university .

The owen m. sylvester photograph collection (1942-1943, undated) contains 32 black-and-white photographs taken at tule lake incarceration camp in newell, california in november 1943 . The majority of the photographs were taken inside the tule Lake incarceration camp, the stockade area, imprisoned japanese americans, and members of the 772nd military police battalion .

The collection contains documents by and about the japanese-american experience during world war ii. The tomo foundation in illinois donated the collection, which contains documents . The collection was created by the Tomo foundation, a foundation in Illinois, and California State University .

Collection includes scrapbooks filled with news clippings on japanese american incarceration, dated 1942-1980s . Collection includes loose issues of pacific citizen, kashu mainichi, rafu shimpo, and maui kanyaku imin (centennial edition)

Collection includes non-war relocation authority documents issued in the incarceration camps or that are related to the incarceration . Japanese-American incarceration camps during world war ii were administered by the war relocation authority . Camp incarcerees independently wrote and distributed many of their own documents associated with the camp newspapers, camp stores, school publications .

Many non-governmental groups sought redress for japanese americans incarcerated during world war ii . The collection contains reports, correspondence, publicity, and other documents issued by the committee on resettlement of j. american student relocation council, ymca, american friends service committee, and j. citizens league .

War relocation authority (wra) was created on march 18, 1942, by executive order of the president, no. 9102 . This new civilian agency was to be responsible for "the relocation (of evacuees) in appropriate places, providing for their needs in such manner as may be appropriate, and supervising their activities"

Rev. wendell l. miller was pastor of the university methodist church, los angeles . He became involved in local politics when gambling and prostitution began edging toward the area surrounding the university of southern california (usc) campus . He founded the citizens independent vice investigating committee (c.i.v.c.), which also campaigned against crime and corruption in city hall, ultimately resulting in the recall of mayor frank l. shaw .

Papers of two generations of the smith family, dr. frank herron smith and his son dr. morris eugene “gene” smith . Collection includes vintage broadsides and government reports on the incarceration of japanese americans during world war ii .

The california folklore miscellany collection is comprised of material documenting various aspects of north bay history, with a focus on beliefs, folkways, folk speech, historical characters, legends, pioneer stories and children's lore . The majority of the materials were gathered from folklore classes taught by dr. hector lee at sonoma state university .

The gaye lebaron collection houses the research material of newspaper columnist gaye lebaron, relating to the north bay region of california . files hold support materials for more than 8,200 newspaper columns . included are research notes, correspondence, newspaper clippings, monographs, local documents, journal issues, photographs, oral histories, and ephemera .

These materials are from box 73 and 74 of the frank chin papers . They contain personal and professional correspondence between frank chin and michi weglyn relating to particular projects on which . either author was working as well as files related to the day of remembrance tribute to michi . Weglyn .

The collection contains photographs and albums of the japanese in the united states, mainly washington, california, colorado, and utah . The photographs include family portraits and snapshots capturing their community activities and local events, such as picnic, wedding, funeral, local associations’ activities, etc., mostly taken in the early 1900s . The taenaka family photographs depict their lives as japies immigrants, nisei children, and kibei soldier participating in the war .

The robert billigmeier collection is comprised of materials collected during his work and stay at the tule lake incarceration camp conducting research for the university of california’s japanese evacuation and resettlement study (jers) The collection includes: photographs taken during his time at the camp; scrapbook created by students at tule Lake in 1942; camp publications; reports and manuscripts; and student writings .

Collection of nine images documents the detention of a group of indonesian seamen in 1947 as they await the outcome of deportation proceedings in the federal courts . The images show roughly 200 men at an immigration detention center in downtown san francisco, at the southern pacific depot in San Francisco, and on ship called the "marine lynx"

An American history digitization project visit visit japanese.org.uk . The project is a collaboration between Japan and the U.S. to digitize an American history book . The collection includes oral histories of marilyn fordney, george wakiji, santa anita racetrack, gila river; morris abe of tule .

The japanese american oral history project features oral histories with narrators who talk about their lives, pre and post world war ii, but most specifically, about their experience being incarcerated in camps during world war II . The project features narrators talking about their experiences in camps .

The children's village at manzanar oral history project features oral histories with narrators who talk about their lives, pre and post world war ii, but most specifically, about their experience . The project is based on the oral histories of people living in Japan and their experiences in Japan .

Oral history project documents the lives of japanese americans who lived in the san fernando valley . Participants are multi-generational, with many who experienced firsthand internment and prejudice during world war ii. The narrators also shared stories of farming, family emigration from japan, and the building of their lives and families both before and after the war .

The minidoka incarceration camp photograph album may have been compiled by lona haug, vice-principal of the blk 10 school . The album features a photograph of ben kuroki, a japanese american who served in the united states army force during world war II .

Collection is a family album compiled by a japanese peruvian family . Photographs depict the lives of the japonaise peruvians in 1930-1950 . included are photographs of japanes peruvian workers and landscapes in a plantation, baseball players of asahi, activities of a men's club, aircrafts landed in the field in peru .

The collection includes a diary written by hiroshi fukuwa, kibei nisei of los angeles, california, along with newsletters, clippings, and handwritten notes created/collected in the incarceration camps during world war ii. The diary details his incarceration experiences in the manzanar camp in califorce, the gila river camp in arizona, and the tule lake camp .

The kuwahara family papers contains documentation of the daily life and people incarcerated in the poston camp in arizona during world war II . materials include: junior high school, high school and camp community newsletters in both japanese and english . The collection includes: watercolor paintings of the camp facilities, programs and booklets of the family and community reunions .

The manzanar album contains photographs and newspaper clippings about the riots at the Japanese incarceration camp . The photographs include images of children, barracks, funerals, and two additional photos from a welcome party for dr. furukochi at the koyasan betsuin in los angeles .

The collection contains 16 images of the hiranuma family at the heart mountain incarceration camp in wyoming . The images were taken at a Japanese American history digitization project visit partner csu.com . The project is a collaboration between csu and the Japan-U.S. government .

The george and mitzi naohara papers consists of photo albums and scrapbooks compiled by george nobuo . The collection includes photos, correspondence, documents, and memorabilia depicting their experiences during world war II. contained are photographs, correspondence and documents . The papers depict their experiences in the manzanar, jerome, and tule lake camps .

The collection includes material from the natsumeda family . The collection contains a yba sunday service program booklet and a granada incarceration camp directory . It was created by csu dominguez hills department of archives and special collections . The copyright is protected under Japanese law .

The takano family papers includes correspondence, photographs, camp newspapers, yearbooks and other documents . The papers covers from prewar through post-war, including the period of the forced evacuation and incarceration during the war and the redress movement in 1980s . included are also letters depicting his struggles to be granted the indefinite leave permit from the gila river incarceration camp in arizona, as a consequence of his answers to “loyalty questions, no. 27 and 28 .

The terminal island/port of los angeles collection documents the neighborhoods, businesses, and landscapes on terminal island, catalina island, san pedro, and other neighboring cities during world war II . The collection documents  neighborhoods and businesses on the island during the war .

The monterey peninsula japanese american citizens league collection features correspondence, meeting minutes, scrapbooks, and event planning materials . The collection also includes materials documenting the history of japonese americans in monterey and wwii incarceration camps. The collection was created by California State University, Monterey Bay .

The heart mountain relocation center was built during the summer of 1942 and received its first contingent of japanese americans on august 12, 1942 . The collection contains community camp council meeting minutes, camp laws, correspondence, the case of people of heart mountain vs. tom yamada, and other documents .

The nisaburo aibara collection features materials from the turlock social club, a local japanese-american community group active between 1939 and 1970 . The collection also features correspondences with reactions, responses, and preparations for the forced evacuation . It contains documents regarding the stockton, turlock and merced assembly centers .

The collection is comprised of photographs from an album created by l. josephine hawes, the chief nurse at the manzanar hospital, and individual photographs collected by ralph p. merritt, the project director of the war relocation center . The collection has been digitized by csu japanese american history digitization project visit partner .

Collection of documents and ephemera from harry bentley wells, teacher at manzanar war relocation center high school and shirley elizabeth elizabeth wells, registered nurse (r.n.) at manzary . The collection includes correspondence, memos, reports, student papers, grade book, grade . book, commencement program, prom invitation, and other memorabilia . copyright restricted .

The sue kato collection consists of personal materials documenting Sue kato's (nee ogata) time serving in world war ii with the women's army auxiliary corps . The collection was created by go for broke national education center and is subject of a digitization project .

The collection features images and documents relating to the ishii family . It was donated by daughters frances and kiyo anne fujimoto . The collection includes 5 digital files (5 digital files) The collection has been digitized by a Japanese American history digitization project .

The long beach and pearl harbor collection consists of materials collected and/or created during the historical society of long beach exhibition, "long beach remembers pearl harbor" materials include documents, correspondence, photographs, and video recordings . The collection was created in the context of an exhibition called "Long Beach remembers Pearl Harbor"

The newspaper photograph collection is made up of photographs that were printed in the long beach press-telegram and independent newspapers, between the 1950s and early 2000s . The collection includes photographs from the long-Beach Press-Telegram, independent newspapers and long-beach press-tlegram . It is made of photographs printed between 1950s-2000s .

The oral history collection at the historical society of long beach is a living collection, growing with each new recording the hslb produces . The collection includes recordings with members of local politics, the lgbtq community, and various community members . It is a collection of 3 digital files (3 digital files)

The risinger photograph collection consists of prints and negatives taken by joseph risinger (10/22/1913 - 03/24/2007) risinger was a staff photographer for the long beach independent and press-telegram papers from the 1940s through the 1970s .

The approximately 7,000 original items include personal and official letters, photographs, diaries, arts and crafts, newsletters, textiles, yearbooks and other publications . The collection documents the people, places, and daily life of japanese americans, primarily those who lived in the once thriving community of pre-war florin in the sacramento region .

The north bay ethnic archive features material related to the forced relocation of northern san francisco bay area residents to the granada (amache) incarceration camp, colorado . Some of the original items are housed with the sonoma county japanese american citizens league (jacl), and were borrowed for digitization courtesy of the jacl . The remainder are housed in special collections .

The collection consists of images and documents from its establishment in 1887 to the mid-20th century . Also included are images of two missions of whittier's first friends church, in kotzebue, alaska; and the friends japanese church in norwalk .

The bain collection, 1920s-1940s, focuses on the daily and recreational activities of the nishimura and yorita families, originally from seattle, washington . densho interviewed collection donor peggie bain in 2004 . The majority of the collection focuses on incarceration of the two families at minidoka, idaho, and tule lake, california .

The sawa collection, early 1900s-1930s, contains images from days, washington. This collection documents the work and leisure activities of the nakashima family, who owned a dairy farm . The collection includes black and white photographs of the family's farm .

The ito collection, 1940s, features photographs of wra camp inmates working on farms in utah and montana under the seasonal leave program . Also included are photographs of a family that relocated to spokane, washington, after world war ii. densho interviewed collection donor toshio ito in 1998 .

The kamikawa collection, 1998, consists of photographs from the nisei veterans reunion in honolulu, hawaii . The collection includes 4 photographic prints, color, and 4 photographs with a partner inclusive unit date 1998 . The photographs were taken at a veterans reunions in Honolulu, Hawaii .

The kaneko collection, 1944, consists of war relocation authority (wra) resettlement photographs of the two families relocated to milwaukee, Wisconsin, during world war ii . The pictures were accompanied by captions worded in a positive manner to encourage japanese americans to leave the camps .

The kashino collection, 1998, focuses on the nisei veterans reunion in honolulu, hawaii. densho interviewed collection donor louise koshino in 1998. The collection is a collection of four photographic prints, color-limited prints, and copyright restricted .

The kawaguchi collection, 1930s, focuses on the shiraishi family, who were farmers from bellevue, washington . The collection contains images of picnics and sports, and includes black and white photographs of agricultural activities, and sports pictures .

The kinoshita collection (1940s, 1970s, and 1980s-1990s) contains photographs from the minidoka concentration camp, idaho . The collection documents the redress movement from its inception, and includes photographs from various japanese American citizens league conventions .

The klimek collection, 1998, documents the pilgrimage to the site of the tule lake concentration camp, california . The photographs depict participants viewing barracks, old foundations from the camp, and castle rock and attending a memorial service at linkville cemetery in klamath falls, oregon .

The kunitugu collection, circa 1918-1930s, focuses on the business and leisure activities of the kunitsugu family of seattle, washington . seattle's prewar nihonmachi area appears in the background of several of the photographs .

The mamiya collection, c.1918-1960s, records the business and leisure activities of the asaba and shibata families of seattle, washington . Dance and graduation programs from the minidoka concentration camp, idaho, are also shown . densho interviewed collection donor yoshi mamiya in 1998 .

The mitsui collection, 1998, documents the nisei veterans reunion in honolulu, hawaii . The collection documents a reunion in honor of the nisai veterans in Honolulu, Hawaii . Add this sharing to facebook, twitter, facebook and twitter to more .

The mitsuoka collection, 1917-1940s, includes photographs of oyster farming in washington state, canneries in alaska, and leisure activities such as skiing . daily life at minidoka concentration camp, idaho, is also well-documented in photographs of cooking, doing laundry, and participating in sports .

The murakami family operated the higo ten-cent store in seattle's international district (formerly nihonmachi) in the early 1900s-1950s, include interior and exterior views of the business and one family portrait . densho interviewed collection donors, sisters ayako and masako murkami in 1997 .

The natsuhara collection, 1920s-1930s, focuses on the agricultural, business, and leisure activities of japanese americans in the white river valley area of washington state . The collection includes 75 photographic prints, black and white, and includes photographs of farm children .

The okawa collection, circa 1918-1940s, features photographs of picnics and other leisure activities of the japanese american community before world war II . The concentration camp at minidoka, idaho, is also shown . The collection includes 16 photographic prints, black and white .

The saul collection consists of images and documents related to japanese american military service during world war II. topics include: 522nd field artillery battalion, 442nd regimental combat team, 100th infantry battalion, rescue of the lost battalion, liberation of dachau, etc. the content of this collection was brought together from multiple sources both organizational and personal . donations were received from the national archives and records administration .

Collection focuses on the tazuma family, owners of a store in seattle's nihonmachi . Collection contains photographs of the family, their store, and recreational activities such as football and judo . Collection includes 6 photographic prints, black and white; 6 documents .

Collection focuses on the tazuma family, owners of a store in seattle's nihonmachi, or japantown . Collection contains photographs of the family, their store, and a photograph of the . family at the minidoka concentration camp, idaho .

The yamada collection, early 1900s-1950s and 1990s, focuses on the iseri family, who resided in the white river valley area of washington state before world war ii and in weiser, idaho, after the war . The photographs depict agricultural life and community activities such as sports, mochitsuki, and religious ceremonies .

The yanagihara collection contains materials from the pre-war, war, and post-war years . The photographs include events such as the redress movement and the memorial to japanese american soldiers at the nisei veterans hall in seattle, washington .

The uchida collection consists of one photograph of matsutake (pine mushroom hunting) hunting, a popular pastime for japanese americans both before and after world war . The collection is one of one photographs of a popular Japanese pastime known as pine mushroom hunting .

The akizuki collection, 1920s-1940s, documents some locations in bellevue, washington, and includes one photo of seattle's public market in the 1920s . The collection includes black and white photographs taken in the 1930s, 1930s and 1940s .

The fugita collection consists of one photograph of fishermen in the rio vista area of california in the 1930s . The photograph is one of one photographs taken by the fugita family collection . The copyright of the photograph is restricted to certain parts of the collection .

The ohashi collection is comprised of photographs of the japanese language school in seattle, washington, when it was used as a hostel for japese americans immediately after world war . The collection includes black and white photographic prints of the s. ohashi family collection .

The tsuji collection consists of two photographs of the japanese language school in seattle, washington, when it was used as a hostel for japese americans immediately after world war II . The collection includes black and white photographs taken in 1946 .

The h. nakagawa collection consists of several photographs of the japanese language school in seattle, washington, when it was used as a hostel for japese americans immediately after world war II . The collection includes black and white photographs taken in the aftermath of World War II .

The nishitani collection consists of several photographs of the oriental gardens, a japanese-run nursery in seattle, washington, prior to world war II . The collection was interviewed collection donor martha nish itani in 1998 . The images are black and white and white .

Collection consists of photographs of strawberry farms, businesses, sawmills, and the church and school activities of the japanese american community on bainbridge island, washington . Collection also includes photographs of the mass removal of japanes from bainsbridge island and manzanar concentration camps .

The densho collection consists of historic photographs of early seattle and surrounding areas, as well as current photographs of historical sites and community events . this collection includes photographs of tule lake, california; minidoka, idaho; the nisei veterans memorial day service in seattle, washington, and photos of the golden potlatch festival .

Collection of the museum of history & industry of seattle, washington, circa 1914-1940s . Staff photographers for the seattle post-intelligencer, a local newspaper, took all the photographs . Collection focuses on the mass removal of japanese americans from bainbridge island and seattle .

The national archives and records administration collection, 1940s, primarily focuses on the ten war relocation authority camps . The collection documents the exploits of soldiers who served with the 100th infantry battalion, the 442nd regimental combat team, the 522 field artillery battalion, and the military intelligence service .

The collection focuses on the seattle buddhist temple archives, early 1900s-1940s . The collection includes black and white photographs of the early 1900-40s and church-related activities such as picnics, entertainment, and the bon odori festival .

The photographs in the collection of the wing luke asian museum, seattle, washington, 1920s-1940s, focus primarily on oyster farming and the minidoka concentration camp, idaho . The images include barracks, schools and leisure activities such as sports and arts and crafts .

The collection of the washington state historical society at tacoma, washington, contains a single photograph of seattle's nihonmachi, or japantown, in the early 1900s . The collection includes a single photographic print, black and white .

The collection contains photographs of the pre-world war ii japanese language school in seattle, washington, Washington . The collection was created by the Japanese language school . The photographs were taken in the early 1900s-1920s and 1930s and 1950s .

The collection of the k. ross toole archives, university of montana, contains photographs of the department of justice internment camp at fort missoula, montana . The photographs were taken at the time of the Department of Justice internment at Fort Missoula .

The uw nikkei alumni association collection contains photographs of japanese american student groups at the university of washington both before and after world war ii.1941-1953 . The collection includes black and white photographs of students at the University of Washington .

The j. egashira collection documents the work and leisure activities of the nakashima family, who owned a dairy farm . The collection includes black and white photographs from the early 1900s-1930s . The images were taken from days, washington.com images .

The seattle times collection contains articles about japanese americans published between 1900 and 1949 . The articles appear to have been originally scanned from microfilm . cropped versions of each article as well as the original full page are available. The articles were selected by densho staff and downloaded from the seattletimes website .

The sato collection consists of three photographs from the personal family collection of rick sato, who was interviewed by densho in 1998 . The photographs were taken in the 1920s-40s and 1950s and 1960s in black and white . densho is the subject of a book called densho, which was published in 1998, which is published in the book densho .

The hayashida family collection includes photos and documents showing daily life of the nishinaka family . Documents are included from the national archives at riverside california relating to the incarceration of ‘alien enemies” at tuna canyon immigration detention station . The collection also includes a small album of photos from 1952 to 1991 .

The Watanabe collection consists of photographs from the personal family collection of edith and harvey watanabe, who were each interviewed separately by densho in 1996 . The collection is based on the personal collection of Edith and Harvey Watanab . The watanabes were interviewed separately in 1996.

The Hashiguchi collection consists of personal photographs from the family of mitsuko hashiguchi, who was interviewed by densho in 1998 . The collection includes 5 photographic prints, black and white, and copyright restrictions are restricted . The images were taken from the collection of a Japanese family collection .

Hirata collection contains one photograph from the personal collection of mary hirata, who was interviewed by densho in 1998 . The photograph is of her four brothers in the military. The photograph was taken in the 1940s and is part of a collection of photographs taken in Japan .

The sasaki collection consists of one photograph from the personal family collection of may k. k. sasaki, who was interviewed by densho in 1997 . The photo is of a japanese american baseball team in 1917 . The collection includes one photograph of the sasaki family collection .

The suguro collection consists of two prewar-era photographs from the personal family collection of ed sugur . The collection includes two photographs of the 1930s-40s . The photographs are black and white and were taken from the collection of the family of ed. Suguro .
